an5.23:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, jātarūpassa upakkilesā, yehi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhaṃ jātarūpaṃ na ceva mudu hoti na ca kammaniyaṃ na ca pabhassaraṃ pabhaṅgu ca na ca sammā upeti kammāya.
an5.23:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five corruptions of native gold. When native gold is corrupted by these it’s not pliable, workable, or radiant, but is brittle and not completely ready for working.

an5.23:1.3.eng: Iron, copper, tin, lead, and silver.

an5.23:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca jātarūpassa upakkilesā, yehi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhaṃ jātarūpaṃ na ceva mudu hoti na ca kammaniyaṃ na ca pabhassaraṃ pabhaṅgu ca na ca sammā upeti kammāya.
an5.23:1.4.eng: When native gold is corrupted by these five corruptions it’s not pliable, workable, or radiant, but is brittle and not completely ready for working.

an5.23:1.5.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, jātarūpaṃ imehi pañcahi upakkilesehi vimuttaṃ hoti, taṃ hoti jātarūpaṃ mudu ca kammaniyañca pabhassarañca na ca pabhaṅgu sammā upeti kammāya.
an5.23:1.5.eng: But when native gold is free of these five corruptions it becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and ready to be worked.

an5.23:1.6.pli: Yassā yassā ca piḷandhanavikatiyā ākaṅkhati—yadi muddikāya yadi kuṇḍalāya yadi gīveyyakāya yadi suvaṇṇamālāya—tañcassa atthaṃ anubhoti.
an5.23:1.6.eng: Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a ring, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland.

an5.23:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcime cittassa upakkilesā, yehi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhaṃ cittaṃ na ceva mudu hoti na ca kammaniyaṃ na ca pabhassaraṃ pabhaṅgu ca na ca sammā samādhiyati āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an5.23:2.1.eng: In the same way, there are these five corruptions of the mind. When the mind is corrupted by these it’s not pliable, workable, or radiant. It’s brittle, and not rightly immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.

an5.23:2.3.eng: Sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

an5.23:2.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca cittassa upakkilesā yehi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhaṃ cittaṃ na ceva mudu hoti na ca kammaniyaṃ na ca pabhassaraṃ pabhaṅgu ca na ca sammā samādhiyati āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an5.23:2.4.eng: These are the five corruptions of the mind. When the mind is corrupted by these it’s not pliable, workable, or radiant. It’s brittle, and not rightly immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.

an5.23:2.5.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, cittaṃ imehi pañcahi upakkilesehi vimuttaṃ hoti, taṃ hoti cittaṃ mudu ca kammaniyañca pabhassarañca na ca pabhaṅgu sammā samādhiyati āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an5.23:2.5.eng: But when the mind is free of these five corruptions it’s pliable, workable, and radiant. It’s not brittle, and is rightly immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.

an5.23:2.6.pli: Yassa yassa ca abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an5.23:2.6.eng: You become capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which you extend the mind, since each and every one is within range.

an5.23:3.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhaveyyaṃ—ekopi hutvā bahudhā assaṃ, bahudhāpi hutvā eko assaṃ; āvibhāvaṃ, tirobhāvaṃ; tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gaccheyyaṃ, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ kareyyaṃ, seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāno gaccheyyaṃ, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṃ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kameyyaṃ, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve pāṇinā parimaseyyaṃ parimajjeyyaṃ yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteyyan’ti,
an5.23:3.1.eng: If you wish: ‘May I wield the many kinds of psychic power—multiplying myself and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful, controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.’

an5.23:3.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an5.23:3.2.eng: You’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an5.23:4.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇeyyaṃ—dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike cā’ti,
an5.23:4.1.eng: If you wish: ‘With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, may I hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.’

an5.23:4.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an5.23:4.2.eng: You’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an5.23:5.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajāneyyaṃ—
an5.23:5.1.eng: If you wish: ‘May I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with my mind.

an5.23:5.2.pli: sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.2.eng: May I understand mind with greed as “mind with greed”,

an5.23:5.3.pli: vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ vītarāgaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.3.eng: and mind without greed as “mind without greed”;

an5.23:5.4.pli: sadosaṃ vā cittaṃ sadosaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.4.eng: mind with hate as “mind with hate”,

an5.23:5.5.pli: vītadosaṃ vā cittaṃ vītadosaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.5.eng: and mind without hate as “mind without hate”;

an5.23:5.6.pli: samohaṃ vā cittaṃ samohaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.6.eng: mind with delusion as “mind with delusion”,

an5.23:5.7.pli: vītamohaṃ vā cittaṃ vītamohaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.7.eng: and mind without delusion as “mind without delusion”;

an5.23:5.8.pli: saṅkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ saṅkhittaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,

an5.23:5.9.pli: vikkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ vikkhittaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,

an5.23:5.10.pli: mahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ mahaggataṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,

an5.23:5.11.pli: amahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ amahaggataṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,

an5.23:5.12.pli: sauttaraṃ vā cittaṃ sauttaraṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.12.eng: mind that is not supreme as “mind that is not supreme”,

an5.23:5.13.pli: anuttaraṃ vā cittaṃ anuttaraṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.13.eng: and mind that is supreme as “mind that is supreme”;

an5.23:5.14.pli: samāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ samāhitaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.14.eng: mind immersed in samādhi as “mind immersed in samādhi”,

an5.23:5.15.pli: asamāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ asamāhitaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,
an5.23:5.15.eng: and mind not immersed in samādhi as “mind not immersed in samādhi”;

an5.23:5.16.pli: vimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ cittanti pajāneyyaṃ,

an5.23:5.17.pli: avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ avimuttaṃ cittanti pajāneyyan’ti,

an5.23:5.18.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an5.23:5.18.eng: You’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an5.23:6.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussareyyaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattārīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe—amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapannoti, iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussareyyan’ti,
an5.23:6.1.eng: If you wish: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. May I remember: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.” May I recollect my many past lives, with features and details.’

an5.23:6.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an5.23:6.2.eng: You’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an5.23:7.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passeyyaṃ cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajāneyyaṃ—ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannāti, iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passeyyaṃ cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajāneyyan’ti,
an5.23:7.1.eng: If you wish: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: “These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.” And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. And may I understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.’

an5.23:7.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane.
an5.23:7.2.eng: You’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.

an5.23:8.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
an5.23:8.1.eng: If you wish: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an5.23:8.2.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatane”ti.
an5.23:8.2.eng: You’re capable of realizing it, since each and every one is within range.”

an5.230:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of a black snake.

an5.230:1.3.eng: It’s irritable, acrimonious, venomous, fork-tongued, and treacherous.

an5.230:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā kaṇhasappe.
an5.230:1.4.eng: These are the five dangers of a black snake.

an5.230:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcime ādīnavā mātugāme.
an5.230:2.1.eng: In the same way there are five drawbacks of a lady.

an5.230:2.3.eng: She’s irritable, acrimonious, venomous, fork-tongued, and treacherous.

an5.230:2.6.eng: This is a lady’s forked tongue:

an5.230:2.10.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā mātugāme”ti.
an5.230:2.10.eng: These are the five drawbacks of a lady.”

an5.231:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu abhāvanīyo hoti.
an5.231:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities is not admirable.

an5.231:1.3.eng: They’re not accomplished in being well-presented and doing their duties.

an5.231:1.4.eng: They’re not very learned and don’t remember what they’ve learned.

an5.231:1.5.eng: They’re not self-effacing and don’t enjoy self-effacement.

an5.231:1.6.eng: They’re not a good speaker and do not enunciate well.

an5.231:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu abhāvanīyo hoti.
an5.231:1.8.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is not admirable.

an5.231:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu bhāvanīyo hoti.
an5.231:2.1.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is admirable.

an5.231:2.3.eng: They’re accomplished in being well-presented and doing their duties.

an5.231:2.4.eng: They’re very learned and remember what they’ve learned.

an5.231:2.6.eng: They’re a good speaker who enunciates well.

an5.231:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu bhāvanīyo hotī”ti.
an5.231:2.8.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is admirable.”

an5.232:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo ca.
an5.232:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.

an5.232:1.3.pli: Sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an5.232:1.3.eng: They’re ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.232:1.4.pli: bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā;
an5.232:1.4.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.232:1.5.pli: kalyāṇavāco hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an5.232:1.5.eng: They’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.

an5.232:1.6.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an5.232:1.6.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.232:1.7.pli: āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an5.232:1.7.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.232:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cā”ti.
an5.232:1.8.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.”

an5.233:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu āvāsaṃ sobheti.
an5.233:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities graces the monastery.

an5.233:1.3.eng: They’re ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.233:1.4.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.233:1.5.pli: kalyāṇavāco hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an5.233:1.5.eng: They’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.

an5.233:1.6.pli: paṭibalo hoti upasaṅkamante dhammiyā kathāya sandassetuṃ samādapetuṃ samuttejetuṃ sampahaṃsetuṃ;
an5.233:1.6.eng: They’re able to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire those who approach them with a Dhamma talk.

an5.233:1.7.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
an5.233:1.7.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.233:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu āvāsaṃ sobhetī”ti.
an5.233:1.8.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities graces the monastery.”

an5.234:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu āvāsassa bahūpakāro hoti.
an5.234:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities is very helpful to the monastery.

an5.234:1.3.eng: They’re ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an5.234:1.4.eng: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an5.234:1.5.eng: They repair what is decayed and damaged.

an5.234:1.6.pli: mahā kho pana bhikkhusaṅgho abhikkanto nānāverajjakā bhikkhū gihīnaṃ upasaṅkamitvā āroceti:
an5.234:1.6.eng: When a large mendicant Saṅgha is arriving with mendicants from abroad, they go to the lay people and announce:

an5.234:1.7.pli: ‘mahā kho, āvuso, bhikkhusaṅgho abhikkanto nānāverajjakā bhikkhū, karotha puññāni, samayo puññāni kātun’ti;
an5.234:1.7.eng: ‘A large mendicant Saṅgha is arriving with mendicants from abroad. Make merit! Now is the time to make merit!’

an5.234:1.8.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
an5.234:1.8.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.234:1.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu āvāsassa bahūpakāro hotī”ti.
an5.234:1.9.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is very helpful to the monastery.”

an5.235:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu gihīnaṃ anukampati.
an5.235:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities shows sympathy to the lay people.

an5.235:1.3.eng: They encourage them in higher ethics.

an5.235:1.4.eng: They equip them to see the truth of the teachings.

an5.235:1.5.eng: When they are sick, they go to them and prompt their mindfulness, saying:

an5.235:1.6.eng: ‘Establish your mindfulness, good fellows, in what is worthy.’

an5.235:1.7.pli: mahā kho pana bhikkhusaṅgho abhikkanto nānāverajjakā bhikkhū gihīnaṃ upasaṅkamitvā āroceti:
an5.235:1.7.eng: When a large mendicant Saṅgha is arriving with mendicants from abroad, they go to the lay people and announce:

an5.235:1.8.pli: ‘mahā kho, āvuso, bhikkhusaṅgho abhikkanto nānāverajjakā bhikkhū, karotha puññāni, samayo puññāni kātun’ti;
an5.235:1.8.eng: ‘A large mendicant Saṅgha is arriving with mendicants from abroad. Make merit! Now is the time to make merit!’

an5.235:1.9.pli: yaṃ kho panassa bhojanaṃ denti lūkhaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā taṃ attanā paribhuñjati, saddhādeyyaṃ na vinipāteti.
an5.235:1.9.eng: And they eat whatever food they give them, coarse or fine, not wasting a gift given in faith.

an5.235:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu gihīnaṃ anukampatī”ti.
an5.235:1.10.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities shows sympathy to the lay people.”

an5.236:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an5.236:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.236:1.3.eng: Without examining or scrutinizing, they praise those deserving of criticism,

an5.236:1.4.eng: and they criticize those deserving of praise.

an5.236:1.5.pli: ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne pasādaṃ upadaṃseti;
an5.236:1.5.eng: Without examining or scrutinizing, they arouse faith in things that are dubious,

an5.236:1.6.pli: ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne appasādaṃ upadaṃseti;
an5.236:1.6.eng: and they don’t arouse faith in things that are inspiring.

an5.236:1.7.eng: And they waste a gift given in faith.

an5.236:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an5.236:1.8.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.236:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge.
an5.236:2.1.eng: A resident mendicant with five qualities is raised up to heaven.

an5.236:2.3.eng: After examining and scrutinizing, they criticize those deserving of criticism,

an5.236:2.4.eng: and they praise those deserving of praise.

an5.236:2.5.pli: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne appasādaṃ upadaṃseti;
an5.236:2.5.eng: They don’t arouse faith in things that are dubious,

an5.236:2.6.pli: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne pasādaṃ upadaṃseti;
an5.236:2.6.eng: and they do arouse faith in things that are inspiring.

an5.236:2.7.eng: And they don’t waste a gift given in faith.

an5.236:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge”ti.
an5.236:2.8.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an5.24:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an5.24:1.2.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an5.24:1.2.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an5.24:1.3.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an5.24:1.3.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an5.24:1.4.pli: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an5.24:1.4.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.24:1.5.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage.

an5.24:1.6.pli: Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, pheggupi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati;
an5.24:1.6.eng: Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an5.24:1.7.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi;
an5.24:1.7.eng: In the same way, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an5.24:1.8.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an5.24:1.8.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an5.24:1.9.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an5.24:1.9.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an5.24:1.10.pli: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an5.24:1.10.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.24:2.1.pli: Sīlavato, bhikkhave, sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi;
an5.24:2.1.eng: An ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an5.24:2.2.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an5.24:2.2.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an5.24:2.3.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an5.24:2.3.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an5.24:2.4.pli: nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an5.24:2.4.eng: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.24:2.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi pāripūriṃ gacchati, pheggupi pāripūriṃ gacchati, sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati;
an5.24:2.5.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would all grow to fullness.

an5.24:2.6.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sīlavato sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi;
an5.24:2.6.eng: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an5.24:2.7.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an5.24:2.7.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an5.24:2.8.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an5.24:2.8.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an5.24:2.9.pli: nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanan”ti.
an5.24:2.9.eng: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”
